Award.AwardTitle: Risk Modeling and Cyber Defense Exercise for Critical Infrastructures Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many critical infrastructures, such as the power grid, are complex cyber physical systems (CPS). Protecting these systems against cyber-attacks is of paramount importance to national security and economic well-being. Risk assessment considering cyber-attacks against critical infrastructures is not well understood due to ever growing, dynamic threat landscape coupled with complex cyber-physical interactions in these systems. In addition, there is a compelling need to create environments in which realistic attack-defense experiments (including risk assessment and risk mitigation) and training exercises can be safely conducted to advance the science and workforce development in this important area of national need.

This project has two key goals: (1) the short-term goal is to design, develop, and demonstrate a cyber defense exercise for improving the security of CPS systems in alignment with the NIST/US Ignite Global Cities Team Challenge; and (2) the long-term goal is to explore fundamental models and algorithms for cyber risk assessment and mitigation. The project makes synergistic federation of three existing security testbeds hosted at Iowa State University and the University of Southern California to create a realistic environment for conducting CPS security experimentation and security preparedness and training exercise, like the North American Reliability Corporation (NERC) GridEx. The intellectual merit of the project lies in two key contributions: (i) realistic experimentations on CPS security testbed federation, and (ii) the development of a novel methodology for cyber risk modeling of CPS systems. The broader impacts of the project lie in developing realistic attack-defense scenarios and learning/training modules that enable academic researchers, students, and industry practitioners to systematically understand, analyze, and improve the security and resiliency of critical infrastructures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research team led by Dr. Govindarasu, PI, from Iowa State University (ISU) incorporated cyber risk modeling methodology and associated mitigation algorithms into ISU's “PowerCyber” testbed, a CPS security testbed infrastructure for the smart grid, and demonstrated realistic attack-defense experimentations. In particular, he demonstrated realistic use-cases of attack-defense scenarios, including 2015 cyber attack on Ukrainian power grid and its potential mitigations. The lessons learned from these attack experimentations have helped develop effective mitigation algorithms/strategies. The system models, attacks modules, and mitigation modules have been bundled into different "storyboards" that enable study of various realistic attack-defense use-cases. The access to the testbed, along with storyboards, have been disseminated to a broader academic and industry community.

Leveraging ISU PowerCyber testbed, Dr. Govindarasu's team also has developed a cybersecurity training curriculum that includes a set of hands-on learning modules focusing on attacks and defenses, and a training manual. The key aspect of the training modules is that they align with NERC CIP compliance that provides hands-on experience to utility professionals in cyber reconnaissance, vulnerability assessment, configuration management, and firewall technology. This cybersecurity training curriculum was successfully delivered to industry professionals at the NERC GridSecCon 2015 and 2016 conferences, in which a total of ~65 industry professionals have benefited through these training sessions. Another salient feature of this training session is that each team of participants is given an instance of a SCADA testbed environment using which they learn and practice cybersecurity tools and techniques, and all were done via remote access to the testbed.

Dr. Jacobson, Co-PI, from Iowa State University led the effort to design, implement, and host CPS-Cyber Defense Competition (CPS-CDC) incorporating three critical infrastructure components, namely, Internet, power grid, and water distribution system into ISU’s ISERINK testbed infrastructure. The first CPS-CDC was successfully hosted at ISU in 2016 and the second edition was hosted in 2017. Both events were great success from the perspective of inquiry-based learning for students in attack-defense on critical infrastructures. A total of 200+ students had participated in these competitions as members of Blue team (defenders) and several security professionals from industry and Iowa National Guard have participated as members of Red team (attackers) or Green team (normal users).

Alefiya Hussain, Co-PI, from USC/ISI focused on developing a curriculum and set of exercises targeted at high school and undergraduates for CPS security. She also integrated some of these modules in her undergraduate communications class at USC and have also organized a summer school program. Dr. Hussain hosted seven high school students in the summer of 2016 and 12 students in summer of 2017 at USC/ISI for a full time internship. The internship lasted for a period of five weeks. During this time, the students learned how to model cyber physical systems on the DETER testbed and conduct experiments to study the security of such systems. 

Dr. Hussain also incorporated the topic of CPS security into the curriculum for an undergraduate class on advanced networked systems. The class covered topics on designing networked and distributed systems. The topics included focused on how the emergence of ubiquitous technology such as low cost sensors and actuators that impact the security of such systems. The class includes a project to design a distributed cyber physical system and secure it at one or more critical sensors sites. Dr. Hussain taught this class in Spring 2016 and 2017. In 2016, she had 47 students an in 2017, she had 74 students who successfully completed this project.

In addition, Dr.Hussain has developed several CPS models and scenarios that can be executed on the DETER testbed for security experimentation and continues to support requests from the community to extend the models for their research needs.
